Does your job search seems to drag on month after month without producing results? So what do you do to stay sane as your job search drags on? First, take a good close look at how you have been conducting your search. It's possible that the lack of traction is related to your current process and practices. For instance, many job seekers understand the importance of networking but they don't actually do it. Next, here are some ideas for staying sane: - Visit your college career center - Take a bridge job - Take some self-assessment tests to learn more about You - Accept and release the past - Don't let the "shoulds" hold you back - Don't let negative people get you down - Follow what you enjoy most doing - Do some projects at home or in your community - Reduce expenses - Join meet-up groups virtually and in person - Be social, Go to weekly networking events near you - Go to professional gatherings in your industry - Volunteer, Do pro bono work, Help others - Be a mentor - Support other job seekers you may know - Visit your local public library - Don't give up - Go for walks, Get out of the house - Take a breather, Give yourself grace - Be disciplined, Set priorities and stick to them - Be open to doing something different, something new - Start a small business - Take courses, Learn something new every day Finally, don't beat yourself up over the lack of results. This 2024 job market is very weird right now. Hang in there. It will get better.

ğŸš¨ Featured #LinkedInQuestion ğŸš¨: I'm in career transition and someone offered their connections to help me. When leveraging someone else's connections, do you only contact the connections for the companies that you have applied to or is there a certain process that should be used? ANSWER from Brenda MellerğŸ¥§: great question! The good news is that this person is volunteering to be of service to you. Here's what I would do: 1. Look at that person's connections and see if there is anyone who works for one of your target companies. 2. Message the person, tell them the name of the person, and ask if they would be open to making a LinkedIn introduction. I'd use this text (or some variation): "Hi Laurie, thanks again for offering to leverage your connections to help me during my job search. I see you're connected to Bobbi Smith who works at ABC Company, which is one of my target companies. Would you be open to introducing us via a LinkedIn message? Thanks! Brenda Meller" 3. Then, after they do the LinkedIn message introduction, reply to the group thread first and say something like this "Hi Bobbi, nice to meet you here. I'll follow up separately and invite you to connect on LinkedIn." 4. Keep the original person in the loop as you go through the process. Let them know when you've made contact with their connection, as well as well you eventually land your next role. Thank them and offer to be a resource to them in the future to return the favor. Hope this helps!

Today's post contains my final top tips on how to create a stand out LinkedIn Profile for anyone who is job searching or considering a career change. If you are reviewing your profile then have a look at the past few days for some key advice and then read on to make sure your profile is complete before you start applying for roles. ğŸ‘Œ Recommendations Absolutely crucial to have recommendations from all stages of your career. Start with education and ask teachers or professors then move onto all of your roles and focus on colleagues, managers, leaders and clients. Consider asking them to note specific projects or pieces of work and to use any keywords or phrases too. Remember that they must be directly connected with you on LinkedIn so a 1st connection. Be nice - give a recommendation back ğŸ† Accomplishments This is not every pub quiz you won or scout badge you ever received but all of that extra learning and development you have done throughout your career. If you have certificates then even better! ğŸ¸ Interests Sadly not where you can list all of your hobbies folks. This section pull s information automatically from organisations you are following and groups you are in. Rarely looked at but worth seeing what companies you are following and if you can enhance it a little. ğŸŒ If you are looking for roles internationally then you can translate certain parts of your profile into another language. Head to LinkedIn Help to get a full breakdown of how to do this as there are several steps.
